key_title: Key to the species of Calotis

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Calotis
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (1999). Calotis. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Ray florets minute, much shorter than involucral bracts, yellow-green; disc florets fertile; hairy annuals, under 15 cm high
Ray florets conspicuous, white, mauve or yellow; disc florets sterile; perennials mostly taller than 15 cm

Pappus of (usually 2) awns alternating with an equal number of scales; leaves spathulate, toothed or shallowly lobed apically (often c. fan-shaped), often with dilated, stem-clasping bases; ray florets mauve
Ray florets yellow; plants taprooted; leaves scattered; stems freely branched, plants often sub-shrubby
Ray florets white, mauve or blue; plants rhizomatous or stoloniferous; leaves all or mostly basal; scapes unbranched or few-branched
Awns of 2 distinct sizes, 2 long and erect, and 3–6 smaller and spreading; ray florets less than 4 mm long; mostly rocky places from near Melbourne eastwards, rare in west
Awns all more or less of equal size; ray florets longer than 4 mm; mostly sandy ground in north-west
Plants hairy, rarely taller than 30 cm; awns 2, spreading at right angles to flattened, tuberculate faces of cypsela
Plants glabrous, mostly 30 cm high or more; awns 2–4 (rarely 5), if only 2 then these in same plane as the flattened body of the smooth cypsela
Leaves deeply pinnatisect or bipinnatisect, with lobes only c. 1 mm wide; cypselas winged
Leaves entire to toothed, or if ever pinnatisect, then division more than 1 mm wide; cypselas wingless

Plants glabrous to sparsely strigose, strongly stoloniferous, growing in heavy soils prone to inundation; awns of cypsela 5–8, subequal, or those above marginal ridges distinctly shorter than those above faces
Plants hirsute to villous, rhizomatous to weakly stoloniferous, generally not growing in swampy areas; major awns of cypsela 4 or 5, alternating with shorter, finer, plumose secondary awns
Awns in 2 rings, those in narrow central ring fine and plumose; apparently very rare or extinct, known only from Mitta Mitta area
Awns in a single ring; widespread species
